text: “I’ll try to change my fate.” The words slipped out faster than I meant them to—and as soon as I said them, I felt the weight of what they really meant.
Alicia smiled—gentle, yet never reaching her eyes. “Many people say that.”
She slowly turned her glass. The amber liquid rippled in circles, catching the firelight as it moved.
“But fate doesn’t listen. You think you’re changing it—but really, you’re just walking a little farther down the road it already laid for you.”
“And what about you?” I asked. “Do you believe in fate—or do you fight it?”
Her hand paused on the rim of the glass, her gaze settling on the fire. “I used to think I could win.”
The flames flickered, a spark landing on her sleeve. She brushed it away without looking. For a brief instant, I saw a shadow pass through her eyes—not fear, but exhaustion.
“Fate isn’t a die,” she murmured. “It doesn’t change its number just because you will it to.”
She was quiet for a moment, then smiled faintly. “Maybe. But if I could, I’d rather not have tried at all.”
Her smile was brief and fragile—like a curtain drawn over an unhealed wound. The firelight wavered in her eyes, and for a moment, even the air felt cold.
